newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chip stock and bonds rally, dollar falls again.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chip stock and bonds rally, dollar falls again.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks and bonds rebounded Thursday as Wall Street welcomed plans to lower the capital gains tax rate.

The dollar fell for the third day in a row, to its lowest level in a month against the German mark and Japanese yen, amid concerns that central banks would sell dollars to halt its two-year-old rally.

The Dow Jones industrial average was up 50.97 points at 7,136.62 as it recaptured part of Wednesday's 140-point plunge. At one time, the blue-chip index was up nearly 130 points before profit-taking trimmed the gain.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,403 to 1,097 on heavy volume of 534 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The market's bounce went against conventional wisdom that news of a proposal to make a capital gains tax cut effective as of Wednesday would unleash a wave of pent-up selling on Thursday.
"It was definitely a shock," Jay Meagrow, institutional trader at McDonald & Co. said of the market's action on Thursday. "I didn't see it coming."
After the stock market closed Wednesday, the Republican chairmen of the congressional tax-writing committees said they would propose setting May 7, as the effective date for a capital gains tax.
The tax cut would allow investors to keep more of their profits when they sell stocks.
But lightening the capital gains tax burden also makes investing in stocks more attractive, a view that held the day Thursday, analysts said.
"The demand for stocks seems to be the dominant factor," said Robert Stovall, president Stovall/Twenty-First.
The Nasdaq Composite index rose 7.92 points to 1,330.83.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, or $3.44 per $1,000 face value, lowering its yield to 6.94 percent from 6.96 percent on Wednesday. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
The dollar fell to its lowest level in a month against the mark and yen as concerns grew that central banks would sell dollars to halt its two-year-old rally.
The dollar fell to 123.75 yen in late New York trading from 125.08 late on Wednesday, and it lost more than a pfennig against the mark to 1.7085 from 1.7195.
Precious metals prices gained, with gold for June delivery on the COMEX in New York closing up $2.40 an ounce at $344.80.
The strength of the dollar against yen in particular has been partly to blame for gold's slide to four-year lows earlier this year.
A rally in gasoline prices tied to rumours of production problems at southern refineries and signs that OPEC might tighten its exports combined to push oil prices higher.

At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for June delivery closed 72 cents higher at $20.34 a barrel. June gasoline rose 1.58 cents a gallon to close at 62.50 cents and June heating oil rose 1.30 cents a gallon to 54.38.

Overseas, London's leading FTSE 100 index closed up 42.9 at a record high of 4,580.4 after being down around 20 points at its worst. In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei average was 12.91 points higher at 20,061.81.
